questions.question: The quadratic function $f(x) = 2x^2 + 8x + 3$ can be expressed in the form $f(x) = 2(x+p)^2 + q$. The graph of $y = f(x)$ is translated 3 units to the right and 2 units up to give the graph of $y = g(x)$. Express $g(x)$ in the form $a(x-h)^2 + k$.
Find the range of values of $m$ such that the equation $x^2 - 2mx + (m^2 - 5) = 0$ has no real roots.
questions.explanation: Discriminant: $\Delta = 4m^2 - 4(m^2-5) = 4m^2 - 4m^2 + 20 = 20 > 0$ for all $m$. Thus, the equation always has real roots.

questions.question: The equation $kx^2 + (k+3)x + 1 = 0$ has two distinct real roots. Find the range of values of $k$.
questions.explanation: For two distinct real roots: $\Delta > 0$ and $k \neq 0$. $(k+3)^2 - 4k > 0$ gives $k^2 + 6k + 9 - 4k > 0$, thus $k^2 + 2k + 9 > 0$. Also $(k+1)(k-9) < 0$, giving $-1 < k < 9$, with $k \neq 0$.

questions.question: The curve $y = ax^2 + bx + c$ passes through the points $(0, -3)$, $(2, 5)$ and has its axis of symmetry at $x = 1$. Which of the following are true? (Select all that apply)
The function $f(x) = -2x^2 + 12x + k$ has a maximum value of 25. Find the value of $k$.
questions.explanation: Complete the square: $f(x) = -2(x^2-6x) + k = -2[(x-3)^2-9] + k = -2(x-3)^2 + 18 + k$. Maximum value: $18 + k = 25$, thus $k = 7$.

questions.question: A quadratic function $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c$ satisfies $f(1) = 0$, $f(3) = 0$, and $f(0) = -6$. Find the value of $a + b + c$.
The quadratic curve $y = x^2 - 6x + p$ and the straight line $y = qx - 5$ intersect at exactly one point. Express $p$ in terms of $q$.
questions.explanation: For one intersection: $x^2-6x+p=qx-5$, giving $x^2-(6+q)x+(p+5)=0$. Discriminant $=0$: $(6+q)^2-4(p+5)=0$. Expanding: $36+12q+q^2-4p-20=0$, thus $4p=q^2+12q+16$, so $p=\frac{q^2}{4}+3q+4$.
